@dannyjespinoza You are using a particular bot, right? That communicates context or gives a list of possible commands.
The bot space is thus a down the middle attack on Google's core competency on mobile. Their response? Probably aggressive.
Building a good command line tool in a messaging app for a given domain might indeed be valuable...but is arguably more about UX than AI.
Slack's bots constrain the problem in a huge way: by requiring slash commands, they reduce scope and avoid full natural language processing.
Bots that accept unconstrained free text input are essentially stateful/iterated web search. Google-level difficulty to discern user intent.

16/ Hard doesn't mean it's impossible. But consortium sales may prove to be the rate limiting step for private blockchain adoption.

15/ So, to sell private blockchain:
- assemble a consortium
- deal with consortia leverage as buyer
- survive long sales cycles
That's hard!
14/ Thus, even though banks have a lot of money, for these logistical reasons it may be hard to build a large private blockchain company.
13/ They have leverage - private blockchain only exists with consortia's cooperation! - so will be hard to sustain profits at their expense.
12/ Even if they do agree on a commercial vendor, consortia members won't want to create a monster like studios did with Netflix/iTunes.
11/ For similar reasons, it may be easier to get consortia to agree on a pure open source private blockchain than a for-profit option.
10/ That is, FB and Google compete on many things, but can cooperate on Linux as neither party can deprive the other of its contributions.
9/ So even if a consortium *does* agree on a private blockchain, pure open source options may dominate...as they are demilitarized zones.
8/ That is, if history of internet micropayments is any guide, everyone wants to be the troll on the payment bridge - browsers, OS, banks.
7/ Moreover, LTV may not be that high, as consortia may demand totally open source solutions (eg PostChain-like: https://t.co/HvO2uwOBig).
6/ So: oligopsonistic market (few large buyers w/ long sales cycles) means lots of leverage vs private blockchain vendors. CAC will be high.
5/ An additional factor: there are fewer consortia than enterprises. Hence the market is more oligopsonistic. https://t.co/ZZ3zk7fbwo

4/ One inkling of this can be seen here:
https://t.co/o03cEwpdnX https://t.co/kcdNCL7Llt
3/ Private blockchains are more desirable when there is less trust (eg auditability is a goal). But less trust makes consortium sale harder.
2/ If enterprise sales is getting a bill through Congress, consortium sales is passing an international treaty. https://t.co/iHEmAvQJV6
1/ Private blockchains are only useful in the context of multiple economic actors. That's beyond enterprise sales. It's *consortium* sales.

@Noahpinion @mims Moreover, as prescient as Tiebout was, he was focused on individuals alone vs crowdchoice to solve collective action prob.
@Noahpinion @mims That is, what Bewley is optimizing (a mathematical model of public goods) is not what mobile individuals will optimize.

@Noahpinion @mims Today you can already book flights, call cars, buy food, rent lodging, send millions from your phone.
@Noahpinion @mims Theory from 35 years ago cited against smartphones that have brought us much closer to Tiebout is IMO not that persuasive.

14/ In summary: US laws blocking construction do exist, their effects are not always good, and they increase price of basic infrastructure.

13/ Third, "moar roads" aren't even possible in the US. $787B meant nothing. Building fast & cheap is illegal.

12/ That is: self-driving cars, ride-sharing, drone delivery, and hyperloops take cars *off* the roads. Like email reduced need for postmen.
11/ Second, "moar roads" is to self-driving cars roughly what "moar postmen" is to email.
10/ First, roads aren't innovation. The Interstate Highway was innovative in 1950. Not anymore. Every country has roads. Table stakes.

The tool should have a SAAS component to be kept up to date with the latest security issues and run automatically on your codebase.
But this needs to be baked into a tool and distributed with a standard library. Like gofmt, but for security rather than formatting.
The combination of parseable code and huge open source datasets of bug fixes gives raw material to build and test automatic bug finders.
And we have billions of lines of open source code on GitHub, with revision histories linked to issues mentioning bug fixes.
We already have years of research into dynamic and static checkers (https://t.co/QE3fJL3Z3q) for automatic bug finding.
Wanted: a programming language that makes security a first class consideration. Automatically parse and warn of exploits at compile time.
The $0 alternative? Liberalize the laws blocking ride-sharing, hyperloops, drone delivery, and self-driving cars. https://t.co/HMDcnvnU8A

But perhaps the most interesting question is what happens if the cloud itself starts taking (buying? building?) territory. For another time.
We'll also see significant innovation in legislative regimes as other nations try to attract (pieces of) the global technology cloud.
Singapore and Estonia are far along here. Already set up to start winning as domiciles for global technology (and corresponding tax base).
The ultimate fate of the nation state in this scenario is to become a commodity provider of land, natural resources, and rule sets.
In the long run, though, the increasing mobility of the global technology cloud will discipline the land. Too much demonization, we move.
The cloud has leverage because it knows tech and can move between nations. The land has leverage because it has more guns and people.
The land will want the cloud to pay taxes and help its security forces. The cloud will want the land to open immigration and cut regulation.
But that'll be the primary political axis worldwide. Left vs right torn apart & reassembled into the cloud vs the land.
There will be some collaboration as well. Nationalists need tech to win elections. And tech needs (some) nation states to allow innovation.

A full-throated, jealous defender of borders, language, and culture.
Or a rootless cosmopolitan with a laptop, bent on callow disruption.

These are two separate trends - the return of nationalism and the rise of technology. Opposed to DC consensus, and to each other.
The postwar Bush/Clinton consensus is being ripped in two - the land below vs the cloud above. Nationalist socialism vs global technology.

@dandolfa Yes, & I don't actually think the dollar is displaceable offline. But online is another matter. USD not good for digital goods.
Incidentally, this is why ideological fervor can have real world value. Not for sale at any price: extremely high trust internal network.
The larger that value, the stronger the bonds between peers and the more capital/effort it would take to break up the trust group.
Can quantify trust in many ways, but a useful one is the "Indecent Proposal" metric: the dollar threshold for a trusted party to defect.
@dandolfa Indeed. That would arguably be the prior probability - prior to 2008.
Pragmatism: not trusting major banks after 2008 is not quite the same as vowing to never trust anyone again. Hard to really do that.

Too much trust: high exit cost. 
Too little trust: high transaction cost.
Pragmatic hybrid models are interesting.
Put another way: trust is a powerful lubricant for business. Can be shown game theoretically, sociologically, empirically, etc.
The Internet led to a lot of unbundling followed by rebundling. Bitcoin may lead to untrusting, then *retrusting* in new groups.
Bitcoin reduces our need for trust in banks, but not in each other.

10/ Another is that there is significant overhead in placing bets of this kind. A pain to track/organize. Perhaps Bitcoin helps long term...
9/ This is for several reasons, but one is: journalism/academia are primarily status-based economies while VC/finance are $-based economies.

8/ These are interesting norms to compare. 
"Conflict of interest" is norm in journalism/academia
"Money where mouth is": VC/finance

7/ Competing norms.
Conflict of interest: have financial stake? Less credible.
Put money where mouth is: no such stake? Less credible.
6/ To get them to bet in the first place, though, need to get "put your money where your mouth is" back to a cultural norm.

5/ In realtime, the only answer seems to be ask them to bet their beliefs.

https://t.co/AC3A2UByLr

8/ If you build a good v0 of a PostChain and want to pursue it as an open source project, I will help fund it. Tweet at me w/ your demo!
7/ Of course, people running PostChain instances would need to bulk buy BTC to sync their txs to the public Blockchain. Feature, not bug!
6/ This then mirrors the "intranet, not Internet" debate. Blockchain w/o Bitcoin - private blockchain - is an intranet. Not totally useless.
5/ This unites the concepts of "off-chain" & "private blockchain". A local DB of off-chain txs, periodically synced with Bitcoin blockchain.
4/ The key feature of a PostChain would  be the ability to periodically write a summary of off-chain transactions to the public Blockchain.
3/ PostChain would similarly be a Postgres extension that adds support for working with crypto and Bitcoin-related datastructures.
2/ PostGIS provides support for map-related data and range queries within Postgres: https://t.co/tbdpIxv2Bj
1/ Let's grant that Blockchain without Bitcoin made no sense. How could we make it make sense? Perhaps a "PostChain": a PostGIS for Bitcoin.

Bureaucracy is quantified by the number of people who can veto your actions. Generally should be low. Yet if it hits zero, you have no team.
The inverse of bureaucracy is direct personal accountability. (Many quickly find that they preferred bureaucracy.)
The utility of a proposed exit mechanism is inversely proportional to its economic cost. The higher the cost, the less practical the exit.
Because mechanisms for exit reduce maximum scale (and pie size), they tend to be opposed by those currently in control of an institution.
Politics is about the disposition of shared resources. The less that is collectively shared, the less room there is for politics.
A startup has little in the way of politics as there is nothing to loot within the organism. All resources are outside the membrane.
Scale increases the size of the pie, but decreases economic alignment. As N increases, payoff functions begin diverging and politics arises.

@Trey_Sullivan I actually think it was: https://t.co/fS1F7qTQP2

High personal burn, obsolete skills, declining co, unemployed at 40.
There's no zero risk tech job to keep till 60 (see: IBM/MS). But you can: minimize personal burn, own little, keep learning, stay mobile.
To be clear: I think Satya is doing an amazing job at MS. But the folks he kept around were the most startup-y and risk tolerant.

Why was safe MSFT job actually unsafe?
1) high salary -> high personal burn rate
2) skill obsolescence
3) layoffs
https://t.co/6UgtUDS7yE
Bezos quote applies to personal careers too: take calculated risks or risk obsolescence.  https://t.co/CHdxJmjpwp https://t.co/F5cqPucC0L
There's something in there re: conservation of risk. Try to squash your risk to zero, and you end up in industries that systemically fail.
If everyone picks the same safe, risk-adjusted option it stops being quite so safe and risk-adjusted. See: MSFT jobs, sovereign defaults.

.@WilDunne Not my first example :) But, yes, specific accounts would have to like an action (= sign in & approve) for that action to occur.
.@WilDunne Closest thing to this: Hellosign uses Gmail auth to verify that K specific Gmail accounts signed a doc. https://t.co/3CNwLPbHgz
.@WilDunne Right now, AFAIK, no system uses the *particular* people who fave a tweet or like a post as auth credentials. But there could be!

.@WilDunne 
- Think about an FB post
- You see "named likes", the specific people who liked it
- If k-of-n give thumbs up, action is allowed

You'd need to make Social 4FA as smooth as TouchID 3FA.
It could work like Hellosign, with k-of-n social likes before permission is granted.
Regarding 4FA - it will take a while for Bitcoin to hit a billion users, but social networks are already there. So: multisig via FB login?
Once that reaches tipping point, may start to see 3FA w/ TouchID. Already possible to do this today at very security conscious orgs.
More detail: it'll take a little while for TouchID-style biometrics to ramp, but will eventually be part of all Android phones as well.

1FA - Password (what you know)
2FA - Phone (what you have)
3FA - TouchID (what you are)
4FA - Social auth [?] (who you know)

12. And the significance of these forums will grow with technologies like VR that permit greater immersion and peripheral vision.
11. Think of these as non-territorial border zones, where open repudiation of regime is expressed by thousands daily. Feedback amplifies.
10. Thus, the mere presence of an online forum with 100k users that pseudonymously disagree with a regime is an integration test failure.
9. The lowly online discussion forum thus starts to loom large. Crimethinkers gather in numbers to state truths without regime retaliation.
8. Conversely, regime power is minimal in those zones where individuals *and especially organizations* can state truth without retaliation.

7. Regime power is thus maximal in the areas where orgs spontaneously hold untruth rallies
http://t.co/SdjWAMlhwY http://t.co/yV180T9BeR

5. Hence a coerced individual untruth is a *unit test* of regime power
6. An organization (N people) stating untruth is an integration test

3. On their own, a human will generally speak a truth
4. In the presence of regime coercion, the truth can be modified to untruth

More detail
1. A unit test is boolean
2. Product of all unit tests: a boolean integration test
http://t.co/1VEVCYqjUo http://t.co/f8pFk4e8aQ

Thesis: regimes coerce individuals into public untruths as a kind of unit test for compliance.

16/ Intrinsic value apps bootstrap BTC price.
- At min tx fee of 5000 Satoshis per write
- $350/BTC
- $1 buys you 57 writes to Blockchain
15/ True that nonzero price supports mining (though mining has occurred during $0 price, would probably continue even if price hit $0 again)
14/ For intrinsic value apps, arguably more precise than "price can be $0" is "zero direct BTC price dependency for app". But wordier.

11/ The pay-per-action advertising app is more subtle: write to blockchain so that ad network & advertiser agree on whether action occurred.

10/ Notarization apps obvious (Blockchain as Docusign/Hellosign/Echosign).

http://t.co/fUWPuV3RrN

9/ More examples of intrinsic value apps:
- notarization
- accounting
- pay-per-action advertising
Each uses Satoshis to write to Blockchain
8/ Intrinsic value apps are those that use Blockchain as bookkeeping (like http://t.co/vmfmSyaA3S). They do not require any exchange rate.

7/ Second, there are 3 kinds of Bitcoin apps:
- Intrinsic value ($0 price ok)
- Relative value (any >$0 price ok, eg $0.01)
- Absolute value
6/ For example, selling Bitcoin-related ads, monetizing the bid-ask spread, or using Bitcoin under the hood reduces volatility sensitivity.
5/ Why might this pattern continue? First, many Bitcoin startups have figured out ways to reduce their leverage on raw BTC price.
4/ You can figure this out w/o private data by looking at investment sizes (http://t.co/92OqaxMyv7) and estimating ranges of VC ownership.
3/ However, there are now several Bitcoin-related startups whose valuations have increased substantially more than BTC has over last 18 mos.
2/ This is surprising. Initially appeared that BTC appreciation itself would act as upper bound envelope for appreciation of Bitcoin cos.
1/ It is now clear that buying BTC directly is the Vanguard of Bitcoin, not the Google of Bitcoin. A good bet - but not the best bet.
